'''PeerTube''' is a [[Free software|free]], [[Decentralization|decentralized]], [[Federation (information technology)|federated]] video platform powered by [[ActivityPub]] and [[WebTorrent]], that uses [[peer-to-peer]] technology to reduce load on individual servers when viewing videos.

Started in 2015 by a programmer known as Chocobozzz, development of PeerTube is now supported by the French non-profit [[Framasoft]].<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=https://framablog.org/2018/10/15/peertube-1-0-the-free-libre-and-federated-video-platform/|title=PeerTube 1.0: the free/libre and federated video platform|last=Framasoft|first=Association|date=2018-10-15|website=Framablog|language=English|access-date=2019-05-23}}</ref> The aim is to provide an alternative to centralized platforms such as [[YouTube]], [[Vimeo]], and [[Dailymotion]].

== Operation ==

{{cleanup section|reason=Prose could be more encyclopedic|date=November 2018}}

A PeerTube instance's [[website]] has a simple appearance, with thumbnails directing the user to a video. Each instance is often independent of others in terms of appearance, account management, subscriptions, [[Like button|likes]] and news. Some of them may share the same videos with others by agreeing on their broadcast conditions: they then form federations. Federations are several instances with the same videos, common laws and potentially based on the same monetary system. Videos are common within the federation but each video is stored by the instance that published it. All federations are independent of each other.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.zdnet.fr/blogs/l-esprit-libre/peertube-l-hebergement-libre-de-videos-est-sur-les-rails-39871579.htm|title=PeerTube : l’hébergement libre de vidéos est sur les rails|last=Noisette|first=Thierry|date=2018-07-23|website=[[ZDNet]] France|language=fr|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2019-06-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.lemonde.fr/pixels/article/2018/07/09/peertube-le-youtube-decentralise-reussit-son-financement-participatif_5328501_4408996.html|title=PeerTube, le « YouTube décentralisé », réussit son financement participatif|last=Lion|first=Bastien|date=2018-07-09|work=[[Le Monde]]|access-date=2019-06-25|language=fr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/secteur/high-tech/2018/03/30/32001-20180330ARTFIG00001-peertube-une-tentative-d-alternative-francaise-et-decentralisee-a-youtube.php|title=PeerTube, une tentative d'alternative française et décentralisée à YouTube|last=Verge|first=Pauline|date=2018-03-30|website=[[Le Figaro]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2019-06-25}}</ref>

== Origins and history ==

PeerTube was created by a web developer known as ''Chocobozzz'' as a peer-to-peer alternative to [[YouTube]], utilizing the [[WebTorrent]] protocol to share videos.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/secteur/high-tech/2018/03/30/32001-20180330ARTFIG00001-peertube-une-tentative-d-alternative-francaise-et-decentralisee-a-youtube.php|title=PeerTube, une tentative d'alternative française et décentralisée à YouTube|date=March 30, 2018|website=FIGARO}}</ref> He was contacted in 2017 by Framasoft, which had a campaign called ''Contributopia'',<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://framablog.org/2017/10/09/contributopia-degoogliser-ne-suffit-pas/|title=Contributopia : dégoogliser ne suffit pas|first=Association|last=Framasoft|date=October 9, 2017|website=Framablog}}</ref> the goal of which is to create alternatives to centralized platforms. In order to support him and his work, notably on improving the design and usability, Framasoft hired the developer.

In 2018, Framasoft launched a crowdfunding on {{ill|KissKissBankBank|fr}} which raised €53,100—more than double the initial goal of €20,000.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kisskissbankbank.com/en/projects/peertube-a-free-and-federated-video-platform|title=PeerTube, a free and federated video platform|last=KissKissBankBank|website=KissKissBankBank|language=en|access-date=2019-05-23}}</ref><ref name="auto"/>

A first beta of PeerTube was released in March 2018<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nextinpact.com/news/106357-peertube-youtube-decentralise-passe-en-beta-publique.htm|title=PeerTube : le « YouTube décentralisé » passe en bêta publique|date=March 27, 2018|website=www.nextinpact.com}}</ref> and the first stable version in October 2018. In June 2018, only a few months after the first beta, 113 instances<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.linformaticien.com/actualites/id/49046/apres-youtube-peertube-deja-des-centaines-d-instances.aspx|title=Après YouTube… PeerTube ? Déjà des centaines d’instances !|website=www.linformaticien.com}}</ref> are publicly available on the web that together host more than {{formatnum:10000}} videos.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://instances.joinpeertube.org/instances/stats|title=PeerTube instances|website=instances.joinpeertube.org|access-date=2019-05-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://peertube.live/|title=PeerTube(LIVE)|website=peertube.live|access-date=2019-05-23}}</ref>

In June 2018, as a result of its videos disappearing amid changes regarding the monetization of [[YouTube]] channels, the [[Blender Foundation]] began experimenting with hosting a PeerTube instance to distribute ad-free copies of the foundation's videos.<ref name="blender"/>

== Technology ==

[[File:What is Peertube.webm|thumb|Video introducing PeerTube]]

PeerTube uses [[WebTorrent]] technology. Each server hosts a [[BitTorrent|torrent]] [[BitTorrent tracker|tracker]] and each web browser viewing a video also shares it. This allows to share the load between the server itself and the clients as well as the bandwidth used through [[Peer-to-peer|P2P]] technology.

The system works via a federation of instances run by independent entities. Each PeerTube server can host any number of videos by itself, and can additionally federate with other servers to let users watch their videos in the same [[user interface]]. This federation permits to collectively host a large number of videos in a unified platform, without having to build an infrastructure comparable to that of the web giants. Each server is operated by and stays under the sole administration of a distinct entity.

PeerTube uses the [[ActivityPub]] protocol, a new [[World Wide Web Consortium|W3C]] web standard, in order to allow decentralization and compatibility with other services such as Hubzilla, [[Mastodon (social network)|Mastodon]] or [[Diaspora (social network)|Diaspora*]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.slashgear.com/just-a-few-facebook-twitter-instagram-and-youtube-alternatives-18534631/|title=Just a few Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and YouTube alternatives|date=18 June 2018|publisher=}}</ref> It is for example possible to comment on a video from a Mastodon account. This can create a whole "ecosystem", as opposed to locked-in platforms of the [[Big Four tech companies]]. [[Fediverse|This ecosystem]] aims to be resilient against censorship<ref name="blender">{{cite web|url=https://www.blender.org/media-exposure/youtube-blocks-blender-videos-worldwide/|title=YouTube Blocks Blender Videos Worldwide|first=Blender|last=Foundation|website=blender.org}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://torrentfreak.com/peertube-a-censorship-resistent-youtube-alternative-180623/|title=PeerTube: A 'Censorship' Resistent(sic) YouTube Alternative|date=2018-06-23|website=TorrentFreak|language=en|access-date=2019-05-23}}</ref> and DDoS, the Big Four being an example of [[single point of failure]].

The software relies on the [[PostgreSQL]] [[Database|DBMS]] and is integrated in popular video platforms like Reddit<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://github.com/honestbleeps/Reddit-Enhancement-Suite/pull/5065|title=Add peertube by aliceinwire · Pull Request #5065 · honestbleeps/Reddit-Enhancement-Suite|website=GitHub|language=en|access-date=2019-05-23}}</ref> and Kodi.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://framagit.org/StCyr/plugin.video.peertube|title=Cyrille Bollu / plugin.video.peertube|website=GitLab|language=en|access-date=2019-05-23}}</ref>
